title: mousetRajectory
text: Within community cognitive scientists, analysis movement data becoming popular. continuous measurements promise insights reaction times provide, researchers conducting first tracking experiment may feel overwhelmed novel data handling requirements. Consequently, often resort ---box software restricting analysis choices poorly documented code snippets colleagues. Thus, time spend learning peculiarities certain software (colleagues) also invested learning overarching principles data analysis development analysis routines. aim mousetRajectory provide scientists easy--understand modular introduction analysis mouse-tracking 2D movement data. mousetRajectory provide functions needed analyze first experiment, strongly encourage extend /replace certain modules code; deeper understanding analysis process naturally lead better interpretations results. Therefore, tried make source code easy understand possible even leads slower function execution. recommend inspect understand functions executing (using RStudio Windows Machine, hit F2 inspect source code functions).

title: mousetRajectory
text: can install mousetRajectory CRAN Alternatively, can keep date install latest development version mousetRajectory github.com/mc-schaaf/mousetRajectory :
code: install.packages("mousetRajectory") if(!require("devtools")){install.packages("devtools")} devtools::install_github("mc-schaaf/mousetRajectory")

title: mousetRajectory
text: Currently, following functions featured: is_monotonic() checks whether timestamps make sense warns don’t. is_monotonic_along_ideal() checks whether trajectories make sense warns don’t. time_circle_left() tells time starting area left. time_circle_entered() tells time end area entered. point_crosses() tells often certain value x y axis crossed. direction_changes() tells often direction along x y axis changes. interp1() directs interpolation function awesome signal package. Thus, call library("signal"). time-saving, much wow. Also, attach signal package avoids ambiguity signal::filter() dplyr::filter() search path. interp2() convenience wrapper interp1() rescales time . starting_angle() computes (starting) angles. auc() computes (signed) Area Curve (AUC). max_ad() computes (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation (MAD). curvature() computes curvature. index_max_velocity() computes time peak velocity, assuming equidistant times data points. index_max_acceleration() computes time peak acceleration, assuming equidistant times data points. sampen() computes sample entropy.

title: mousetRajectory
text: Let us assume conducting simple experiment. setup, participants must respond moving mouse cursor starting position (bottom circle, coordinates (0,0)) one two end positions (top circles, coordinates (-1,1) (1,1)):  dat stores simple toy data may reflect pilot results. Let’s inspect structure data:  example, Time reflects time passed since onset imperative stimulus always increases 1 arbitrary unit. real experiment, sensible first pre-processing step double-check order data via is_monotonic() applied Time. , real experiment likely group Time, also variables like subject block identifier. next step, recode coordinates can treat movements left right way. enables us restrict trajectories relevant parts, .e., home left target reached. also allows us extract first dependent measures, InitiationTime MovementTime:  Note filtering data relevant part leads unequal amount data points trajectory (column n). bad news want display average trajectories! One solution problem “time-normalization,” .e., separate linear interpolation x y coordinates certain time points. proposed process done prior computation MAD, AUC, etc. let’s via interp2(), convenient wrapper signal::interp1(): Now ready compute dependent measures like AUC MAD: last step, may want plot average trajectory:  Congratulations, worked trough first mouse-tracking analysis! final note: package currently development. spot bugs improvement suggestions, please let us know filing issue github.com/mc-schaaf/mousetRajectory/issues.
code: library(mousetRajectory) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) head(dat) #> # A tibble: 6 × 5 #>   Trial Target  Time x_coord y_coord #>   <int> <chr>  <int>   <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1     1 left       0    0     0      #> 2     1 left       1   -0.01  0.0140 #> 3     1 left       2   -0.02  0.0278 #> 4     1 left       3   -0.03  0.0416 #> 5     1 left       4   -0.04  0.0554 #> 6     1 left       5   -0.05  0.069  # gg_background has been created previously and is a ggplot object gg_background + geom_path(aes(x_coord, y_coord, group = Trial), dat) dat <- dat %>%   group_by(Trial) %>%   mutate(     # will throw a warning if times are not monotonically increasing     is_ok = is_monotonic(Time)   ) dat <- dat %>%   group_by(Trial) %>%   mutate(     x_coord = ifelse(Target == "left", -x_coord, x_coord),     InitiationTime = time_circle_left(       x_coord,       y_coord,       Time,       x_mid = 0,       y_mid = 0,       radius = 0.2     ),     CompletionTime = time_circle_entered(       x_coord,       y_coord,       Time,       x_mid = 1,       y_mid = 1,       radius = 0.2     ),      MovementTime = CompletionTime - InitiationTime   ) %>%   filter(Time >= InitiationTime & Time < CompletionTime)  dat %>%   group_by(Trial, InitiationTime, CompletionTime, MovementTime) %>%   count() #> # A tibble: 4 × 5 #> # Groups:   Trial, InitiationTime, CompletionTime, MovementTime [4] #>   Trial InitiationTime CompletionTime MovementTime     n #>   <int>          <int>          <int>        <int> <int> #> 1     1             12             84           72    72 #> 2     2             10             76           66    66 #> 3     3             10             79           69    69 #> 4     4              9             83           74    74  gg_background + geom_path(aes(x_coord, y_coord, group = Trial), dat) dat_int <- dat %>%   group_by(Trial) %>%   reframe(     Time_new = 0:100,     x_new = interp2(Time, x_coord, 101),     y_new = interp2(Time, y_coord, 101),   ) dat_int %>%   group_by(Trial) %>%   summarise(     MAD = max_ad(x_new, y_new),     AUC = auc(x_new, y_new),     CUR = curvature(x_new, y_new)   ) #> # A tibble: 4 × 4 #>   Trial     MAD     AUC   CUR #>   <int>   <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> #> 1     1  0.0353  0.0239  1.00 #> 2     2 -0.0274 -0.0183  1.00 #> 3     3  0.0462  0.0314  1.01 #> 4     4  0.126   0.0907  1.04 dat_avg <- dat_int %>%   group_by(Time_new) %>%   summarise(     x_avg = mean(x_new),     y_avg = mean(y_new)   )  gg_background +   geom_path(aes(x_avg, y_avg), dat_avg) +   geom_path(aes(c(0, 1), c(0, 1)), linetype = "dashed") # ideal trajectory

title: Authors and Citation
text: Roland Pfister. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Solveig Tonn. Author. Moritz Schaaf. Author. Robert Wirth. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Pfister R, Tonn S, Schaaf M, Wirth R (2024). “mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists.” Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217–-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217.
code: @Article{,   title = {mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses for behavioral scientists},   author = {Roland Pfister and Solveig Tonn and Moritz Schaaf and Robert Wirth},   journal = {The Quantitative Methods for Psychology},   year = {2024},   volume = {20},   number = {3},   pages = {217–-229},   doi = {10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217}, }

what: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists
title: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists
text: Tool helping psychologists behavioural scientists analyze mouse movement (2-D trajectory) data. Bundles together several functions computing spatial measures (maximum absolute deviation, area curve, sample entropy) providing shorthand often-used procedures.

title: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists
text: can install mousetRajectory CRAN Alternatively, can keep date install latest development version mousetRajectory github.com/mc-schaaf/mousetRajectory :
code: install.packages("mousetRajectory") if(!require("devtools")){install.packages("devtools")} devtools::install_github("mc-schaaf/mousetRajectory")

title: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists
text: Currently, following functions featured: is_monotonic() checks whether timestamps make sense warns don’t. is_monotonic_along_ideal() checks whether trajectories make sense warns don’t. time_circle_left() tells time starting area left. time_circle_entered() tells time end area entered. point_crosses() tells often certain value x y axis crossed. direction_changes() tells often direction along x y axis changes. interp1() directs interpolation function awesome signal package. Thus, call library("signal"). time-saving, much wow. Also, attach signal package avoids ambiguity signal::filter() dplyr::filter() search path. interp2() convenience wrapper interp1() rescales time . starting_angle() computes (starting) angles. auc() computes (signed) Area Curve (AUC). max_ad() computes (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation (MAD). curvature() computes curvature. index_max_velocity() computes time peak velocity, assuming equidistant times data points. index_max_acceleration() computes time peak acceleration, assuming equidistant times data points. sampen() computes sample entropy.

title: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists
text: can find example application well full documentation mc-schaaf.github.io/mousetRajectory/. prefer good, old paper format? Check Pfister et al. (2024)!

title: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists
text: Please report bugs github.com/mc-schaaf/mousetRajectory/issues.

title: Area Under the Curve — auc
text: Computes (signed) Area Curve (AUC) path, defined vectors x y coordinates, compared ideal line passing start end points.

title: Area Under the Curve — auc
code: auc(x_vector, y_vector, x_start, y_start, x_end, y_end, geometric = FALSE)

title: Area Under the Curve — auc
text: x_vector x-coordinates executed path. y_vector y-coordinates executed path. x_start x-coordinate start point ideal line. Defaults first value x_vector. y_start y-coordinate start point ideal line. Defaults first value y_vector. x_end x-coordinate end point ideal line. Defaults last value x_vector. y_end y-coordinate end point ideal line. Defaults last value y_vector. geometric Whether sign areas stem movement reverse direction ideal line reversed. Defaults FALSE, indicating time-based instead geometric interpretation. impacts AUC trajectory monotonically increasing relative ideal line.

title: Area Under the Curve — auc
text: AUC single number (-Inf +Inf).

title: Area Under the Curve — auc
text: ideal line line, line segment, .e., infinite length. supplied vectors assumed ordered time. Counterclockwise deviations ideal line considered positive, clockwise deviations negative computation AUC. Thus, negative AUCs possible.

title: Area Under the Curve — auc
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: Area Under the Curve — auc
code: x_vals <- c(0, 0, 0, 1, 2) y_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 2, 2) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 2), c(0, 2), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  auc(x_vals, y_vals) # counterclockwise deviation: positive #> [1] 2  x_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 2, 2) y_vals <- c(0, 0, 0, 1, 2) auc(x_vals, y_vals) # clockwise deviation: negative #> [1] -2 plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 2), c(0, 2), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  x_vals <- -x_vals auc(x_vals, y_vals) # now it is counterclockwise again #> [1] 2  x_vals <- c(0, 0, 1, 2, 2) y_vals <- c(0, 1, 1, 1, 2) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 2), c(0, 2), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  auc(x_vals, y_vals) # might create small rounding errors; this should be 0 #> [1] 3.330669e-16 all.equal(0, auc(x_vals, y_vals)) # indeed interpreted by R as basically 0 #> [1] TRUE  x_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 1) y_vals <- c(0, 1, 1, 0) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 1), c(0, 0), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  auc(x_vals, y_vals) #> [1] 2 auc(x_vals, y_vals, geometric = TRUE) # note the difference #> [1] 1

title: Curvature — curvature
text: Computes curvature path, defined vectors x y coordinates, compared ideal path, defined start end points path.

title: Curvature — curvature
code: curvature(x_vector, y_vector)

title: Curvature — curvature
text: x_vector x-coordinates executed path. y_vector y-coordinates executed path.

title: Curvature — curvature
text: Single number indicating curvature (1 +Inf).

title: Curvature — curvature
text: supplied vectors assumed ordered time.

title: Curvature — curvature
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: Curvature — curvature
code: x_vals <- c(0, 0, 0, 1, 2) y_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 2, 2) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 2), c(0, 2), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  curvature(x_vals, y_vals) #> [1] 1.414214  x_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 2, 2) y_vals <- c(0, 0, 0, 1, 2) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 2), c(0, 2), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  curvature(x_vals, y_vals) #> [1] 1.414214  x_vals <- c(0, 0, 1, 2, 2) y_vals <- c(0, 1, 1, 1, 2) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 2), c(0, 2), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  curvature(x_vals, y_vals) #> [1] 1.414214

title: xFlips — direction_changes
text: Checks often number sequence changes decreasing monotonically increasing monotonically (vice versa).

title: xFlips — direction_changes
code: direction_changes(numeric_vector)

title: xFlips — direction_changes
text: numeric_vector Numbers, ordered time appearance.

title: xFlips — direction_changes
text: Single number indicating often numeric_vector changes direction (0 +Inf).

title: xFlips — direction_changes
text: supplied vectors assumed ordered time. Values strictly monotonically -/decreasing. .e., c(0, 1, 1, 2) return 0, \(x_n >= x_n-1\) satisfied \(2 <= n <= length(c(0, 1, 1, 2))\).

title: xFlips — direction_changes
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: xFlips — direction_changes
code: direction_changes(c(0, 1, 1, 2)) #> [1] 0 direction_changes(c(0, 1, 1, 0)) #> [1] 1 direction_changes(c(0, 1, 0, 1)) #> [1] 2

what: Time point of maximum acceleration — index_max_acceleration
title: Time point of maximum acceleration — index_max_acceleration
text: Computes index peak acceleration trajectory, defined vectors x y coordinates, assumed equidistant time.

title: Time point of maximum acceleration — index_max_acceleration
code: index_max_acceleration(x_vector, y_vector, absolute = FALSE)

title: Time point of maximum acceleration — index_max_acceleration
text: x_vector x-coordinates executed path. y_vector y-coordinates executed path. absolute negative accelerations (.e., deceleration) included? Defaults FALSE.

title: Time point of maximum acceleration — index_max_acceleration
text: Single number indicating index peak acceleration (1 +Inf).

title: Time point of maximum acceleration — index_max_acceleration
text: supplied vectors assumed ordered time equal time differences.

title: Time point of maximum acceleration — index_max_acceleration
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: Time point of maximum acceleration — index_max_acceleration
code: x_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 3, 6, 10, 12, 14, 15) y_vals <- c(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0) index_max_acceleration(x_vals, y_vals) #> [1] 4 # acceleration maximal between x_vals[4] and x_vals[5]

what: Time point of maximum velocity — index_max_velocity
title: Time point of maximum velocity — index_max_velocity
text: Computes index peak velocity trajectory, defined vectors x y coordinates, assumed equidistant time.

title: Time point of maximum velocity — index_max_velocity
code: index_max_velocity(x_vector, y_vector)

title: Time point of maximum velocity — index_max_velocity
text: x_vector x-coordinates executed path. y_vector y-coordinates executed path.

title: Time point of maximum velocity — index_max_velocity
text: Single number indicating index peak velocity (1 +Inf).

title: Time point of maximum velocity — index_max_velocity
text: supplied vectors assumed ordered time equal time differences.

title: Time point of maximum velocity — index_max_velocity
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: Time point of maximum velocity — index_max_velocity
code: x_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 3, 6, 10, 12, 14, 15) y_vals <- c(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0) index_max_velocity(x_vals, y_vals) #> [1] 5 # velocity maximal between x_vals[5] and x_vals[6]  numbers <- seq(-(3 / 4) * pi, (3 / 4) * pi, by = 0.001) y_vector <- sin(numbers) plot(numbers, y_vector) index_max_velocity(rep(0, length(numbers)), y_vector) #> [1] 2357 abline(v = numbers[index_max_velocity(rep(0, length(numbers)), y_vector)])  which.max(cos(numbers)) # first derivative of sin, max at 0 degrees #> [1] 2357

title: Interpolation aka Time-Normalization — interp2
text: Convenient wrapper signal::interp1() linear interpolation. Assumes want interpolated values xy_old n_xy_new equidistant data points.

title: Interpolation aka Time-Normalization — interp2
code: interp2(time_old, xy_old, n_xy_new = 101)

title: Interpolation aka Time-Normalization — interp2
text: time_old Timestamps xy_old coordinates. xy_old -normalized x y coordinates. n_xy_new Number equidistant timepoints generated. Defaults 101.

title: Interpolation aka Time-Normalization — interp2
text: Vector length n_xy_new interpolated x y values.

title: Interpolation aka Time-Normalization — interp2
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

what: Test if vector is monotonically in-/decreasing — is_monotonic
title: Test if vector is monotonically in-/decreasing — is_monotonic
text: Checks numeric_vector monotonically -/decreasing. particular, always good idea check time stamps trajectory data verify logging worked properly.

title: Test if vector is monotonically in-/decreasing — is_monotonic
code: is_monotonic(numeric_vector, decreasing = FALSE, strict = TRUE, warn = TRUE)

title: Test if vector is monotonically in-/decreasing — is_monotonic
text: numeric_vector Number sequence -checked. decreasing numeric_vector increasing decreasing? Defaults FALSE. strict Must values -/decrease strictly? Defaults TRUE, indicating strict, weak definition monotony applied. warn warning issued numeric_vector monotonic? Defaults TRUE.

title: Test if vector is monotonically in-/decreasing — is_monotonic
text: length-one logical, indicating whether vector monotonic.

title: Test if vector is monotonically in-/decreasing — is_monotonic
text: objects length 0 1 monotonic. Data missing values pass check.

title: Test if vector is monotonically in-/decreasing — is_monotonic
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: Test if vector is monotonically in-/decreasing — is_monotonic
code: is_monotonic(c(1, 2, 3, 4), warn = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE is_monotonic(c(1, 2, 2, 3), warn = FALSE) #> [1] FALSE is_monotonic(c(1, 2, 2, 3), strict = FALSE, warn = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE is_monotonic(c(4, 0, -1, -1, -5),   decreasing = TRUE,   strict = FALSE, warn = FALSE ) #> [1] TRUE

what: Test if vector is monotonically increasing along the ideal trajectory — is_monotonic_along_ideal
title: Test if vector is monotonically increasing along the ideal trajectory — is_monotonic_along_ideal
text: Checks trajectory, defined vectors x y coordinates, monotonically increasing relative ideal line passing start end points.

title: Test if vector is monotonically increasing along the ideal trajectory — is_monotonic_along_ideal
code: is_monotonic_along_ideal(   x_vector,   y_vector,   x_start,   y_start,   x_end,   y_end,   strict = TRUE,   warn = TRUE )

title: Test if vector is monotonically increasing along the ideal trajectory — is_monotonic_along_ideal
text: x_vector x-coordinates executed path. y_vector y-coordinates executed path. x_start x-coordinate start point ideal line. Defaults first value x_vector. y_start y-coordinate start point ideal line. Defaults first value y_vector. x_end x-coordinate end point ideal line. Defaults last value x_vector. y_end y-coordinate end point ideal line. Defaults last value y_vector. strict Must values increase strictly? Defaults FALSE, indicating weak, strict definition monotony applied. warn warning issued trajectory monotonic (relative ideal line)? Defaults TRUE.

title: Test if vector is monotonically increasing along the ideal trajectory — is_monotonic_along_ideal
text: length-one logical, indicating whether trajectory monotonic.

title: Test if vector is monotonically increasing along the ideal trajectory — is_monotonic_along_ideal
text: Computes orthogonal projection trajectory points onto ideal line checks whether distances projection start point monotonic. objects length 0 1 monotonic. Data missing values pass check.

title: Test if vector is monotonically increasing along the ideal trajectory — is_monotonic_along_ideal
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: Test if vector is monotonically increasing along the ideal trajectory — is_monotonic_along_ideal
code: # common use-case: exclude movements that miss the target area and to go back # movement 1: x_vals1 <- c(0, 0.95, 1) y_vals1 <- c(0, 1.3, 1) # movement 2: x_vals2 <- y_vals1 y_vals2 <- x_vals1 # movement 3: x_vals3 <- c(0, -0.1, 0.5, 1) y_vals3 <- c(0, 0.5, 0, 1)  # note that the first two movements are symmetric to the ideal line: plot(x_vals1, y_vals1, type = "l", xlim = c(-0.1, 1.3), ylim = c(-0.1, 1.3)) lines(x_vals2, y_vals2, type = "l") lines(x_vals3, y_vals3, type = "l") lines(c(0, 1), c(0, 1), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  is_monotonic_along_ideal(x_vals1, y_vals1, warn = FALSE) #> [1] FALSE is_monotonic_along_ideal(x_vals2, y_vals2, warn = FALSE) #> [1] FALSE is_monotonic_along_ideal(x_vals3, y_vals3, warn = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE # Note that the third movement is regarded as monotonic although both # x and y coordinates are not. # In contrast, excluding movements based on monotony of the y-coordinate # would exclude the first and third movement: is_monotonic(y_vals1, warn = FALSE) #> [1] FALSE is_monotonic(y_vals2, warn = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE is_monotonic(y_vals3, warn = FALSE) #> [1] FALSE  # Also works if movements go into negative direction: # movement 1: x_vals1 <- c(0, -0.95, -1) y_vals1 <- c(0, 1.3, 1) # movement 3: x_vals3 <- c(0, 0.1, -0.5, -1) y_vals3 <- c(0, 0.5, 0, 1)  plot(x_vals1, y_vals1, type = "l", xlim = c(-1.3, 0.1), ylim = c(-0.1, 1.3)) lines(x_vals3, y_vals3, type = "l") lines(-c(0, 1), c(0, 1), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  is_monotonic_along_ideal(x_vals1, y_vals1, warn = FALSE) #> [1] FALSE is_monotonic_along_ideal(x_vals3, y_vals3, warn = FALSE) #> [1] TRUE

title: (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation — max_ad
text: Computes (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation (MAD) path, defined vectors x y coordinates, compared ideal line passing start end points.

title: (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation — max_ad
code: max_ad(x_vector, y_vector, x_start, y_start, x_end, y_end)

title: (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation — max_ad
text: x_vector x-coordinates executed path. y_vector y-coordinates executed path. x_start x-coordinate start point ideal line. Defaults first value x_vector. y_start y-coordinate start point ideal line. Defaults first value y_vector. x_end x-coordinate end point ideal line. Defaults last value x_vector. y_end y-coordinate end point ideal line. Defaults last value y_vector.

title: (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation — max_ad
text: (signed) MAD single number (-Inf +Inf).

title: (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation — max_ad
text: ideal line line, line segment, .e., infinite length. supplied vectors assumed ordered time. Counterclockwise deviations ideal line considered positive, clockwise deviations negative computation MAD. Thus, negative MADs possible. one value considered maximal, first maximal value returned.

title: (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation — max_ad
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: (signed) Maximum Absolute Deviation — max_ad
code: x_vals <- c(0, 0, 0, 1, 2) y_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 2, 2) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 2), c(0, 2), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  max_ad(x_vals, y_vals) # counterclockwise deviation: positive #> [1] 1.414214  x_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 2, 2) y_vals <- c(0, 0, 0, 1, 2) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 2), c(0, 2), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  max_ad(x_vals, y_vals) # clockwise deviation: negative #> [1] -1.414214 x_vals <- -x_vals max_ad(x_vals, y_vals) # now it is counterclockwise again #> [1] 1.414214  x_vals <- c(0, 0, 1, 2, 3, 6, 3) y_vals <- c(0, 2, 2, 2, 2, 1, 0) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(c(0, 3), c(0, 0), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  max_ad(x_vals, y_vals) # the ideal trajectory has infinite length #> [1] 2  x_vals <- c(0, 1, 2, 3) y_vals <- c(0, 1, -1, 0) plot(x_vals, y_vals, type = "l") lines(x_vals, -y_vals, col = "red") lines(c(0, 3), c(0, 0), lty = "dashed", lwd = 2) # ideal  max_ad(x_vals, y_vals) #> [1] 1 max_ad(x_vals, -y_vals) # the "first" maximal value is returned #> [1] -1

what: mousetRajectory: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists — mousetRajectory-package
title: mousetRajectory: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists — mousetRajectory-package
text: Helping psychologists behavioural scientists analyze mouse movement (2-D trajectory) data. Bundles together several functions compute spatial measures (e.g., maximum absolute deviation, area curve, sample entropy) provide shorthand procedures frequently used (e.g., time normalization, linear interpolation, extracting initiation movement times). informationsee Pfister et al. (2024) doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217 .

title: mousetRajectory: Mouse Trajectory Analyses for Behavioural Scientists — mousetRajectory-package
text: Maintainer: Roland Pfister mail@roland-pfister.net (ORCID) [copyright holder] Authors: Solveig Tonn tonn@uni-trier.de (ORCID) Moritz Schaaf moritz.schaaf@uni-trier.de (ORCID) Robert Wirth robert.wirth@uni-wuerzburg.de (ORCID)

what: Objects exported from other packages — reexports
title: Objects exported from other packages — reexports
text: objects imported packages. Follow links see documentation. signal interp1

title: Sample entropy — sampen
text: Computes sample entropy (sampen), given Richman & Moorman (2000), doi:10.1152/ajpheart.2000.278.6.H2039 .

title: Sample entropy — sampen
code: sampen(   timeseries_array,   dimensions = 2,   tolerance = 0.2,   standardize = TRUE,   use_diff = FALSE )

title: Sample entropy — sampen
text: timeseries_array Array numbers sampen computed. dimensions Number embedding dimensions compute sampen. Sometimes also called "template length". tolerance Tolerance comparisons two number sequences. standardize Whether standardize timeseries_array. use_diff Whether use differences adjacent points.

title: Sample entropy — sampen
text: Single number indicating sampen given parameters (0 +Inf).

title: Sample entropy — sampen
text: suggested Richman & Moorman (2000), doi:10.1152/ajpheart.2000.278.6.H2039 , last possible vector length dimensions considered corresponding vector length dimensions + 1, ensuring sampen estimation low bias introduced length timeseries_array. function deliberately implemented R C-style code. makes function rather slow large timeseries_arrays, enables maximal transparency. overview faster sampen functions R , however, distributed binary need source compilation, see Chen et al. (2019), doi:10.1093/biomethods/bpz016 .

title: Sample entropy — sampen
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: Sample entropy — sampen
code: x_vals <- rep(c(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 1), 20) sampen(x_vals, dimensions = 1, tolerance = 1 / 2, standardize = FALSE) #> [1] 0.3746047 sampen(x_vals, dimensions = 3, tolerance = 1 / 2, standardize = FALSE) #> [1] 0.4314233 sampen(x_vals,   dimensions = 3, tolerance = 1 / 2, standardize = FALSE,   use_diff = TRUE ) #> [1] 0.319137 sampen(x_vals, dimensions = 3, tolerance = 1, standardize = FALSE) #> [1] 0

title: Starting angle — starting_angle
text: Computes angle (degrees) line, defined two points coordinates (x0, y0) (x1, y1), specified axis.

title: Starting angle — starting_angle
code: starting_angle(x0, x1, y0, y1, swap_x_y = TRUE)

title: Starting angle — starting_angle
text: x0 x-value first point. x1 x-value second point. y0 y-value first point. y1 y-value second point. swap_x_y Whether compute angle relative x y axis. Defaults TRUE, indicating angle relative y axis.

title: Starting angle — starting_angle
text: Angle degrees \(-180 <= angle <= 180\).

title: Starting angle — starting_angle
text: angle computed relative x axis, counterclockwise changes counted positive. angle computed relative y axis, clockwise changes counted positive.

title: Starting angle — starting_angle
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217

title: Starting angle — starting_angle
code: # Note that not the mathematical definition of angle is used by default: starting_angle(0, 1, 0, 0) #> [1] 90 starting_angle(0, 1, 0, 0, swap_x_y = FALSE) #> [1] 0 # angles are clockwise and relative to the y-axis.  # Note that return values are in the range [-180, 180], not [0, 360]: starting_angle(0, -1, 0, -1) #> [1] -135 starting_angle(0, 1, 0, -1, swap_x_y = FALSE) #> [1] -45

title: Completion Time — time_circle_entered

title: Completion Time — time_circle_entered

title: Completion Time — time_circle_entered
text: x_vector x-coordinates executed path. y_vector y-coordinates executed path. t_vector Timestamps executed trajectory. x_mid x-coordinate center circle. y_mid y-coordinate center circle. radius radius center circle. include_radius Whether points lying exactly radius included circle. Defaults TRUE. warn whether warning thrown first entry t_vector returned. Defaults TRUE.

title: Completion Time — time_circle_entered
text: Value t_vector first time trajectory circle.

title: Completion Time — time_circle_entered
text: Pfister, R., Tonn, S., Schaaf, M., Wirth, R. (2024). mousetRajectory: Mouse tracking analyses behavioral scientists. Quantitative Methods Psychology, 20(3), 217-229. doi:10.20982/tqmp.20.3.p217
